                    <gmd:citedResponsibleParty>

                            </gmd:organisationName>

                        <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>

                            </gmd:organisationName>
                            <gmd:role>
                                <gmd:CI_RoleCode
                                        codeList="https://schemas.isotc211.org/19115/-3/cit/1.0/codelists.xml#CI_RoleCode"
                                        codeListValue="contributor">contributor

                        </gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                    </gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                </gmd:CI_Citation>
            </gmd:citation>
            <gmd:abstract>
                <gco:CharacterString>Surface water quality monitoring is critical in determining if water quality is meeting the needs of the aquatic environment and requirements for human and livestock use. Water monitoring is also a critical component in watershed management and often is an accurate indicator of adjacent land use and management. The program measures water quality in three main parameters:
- Physical (e.g., dissolved oxygen, water temperature and total suspended solids) 
- Chemical (e.g., nutrients, metals, pesticides) 
- Biological (e.g., bacteria) 
The MRWCC has partnered with Alberta Environment and Parks, and the Counties of Warner, Cardston, and Cypress to conduct a water monitoring program on the Milk River and its tributaries since 2006.
Sampling starts in April and completed October each year. Long term monitoring is essential as data is analyzed to detect changes or trends in water sample results. In the event that the findings of the water quality fall below the established guidelines because of human activities, the MRWCC works to implement reasonable and practical measures to improve the instream water quality.
The full summary of baseline water quality sampling is reported in the 2nd Edition Milk River Transboundary State of the Watershed Report and can be accessed at: www.mrwcc.ca</gco:CharacterString>
            </gmd:abstract>

            </gmd:topicCategory>

                            </gmd:westBoundLongitude>

                                <gco:Decimal>-110.897442</gco:Decimal>
                            </gmd:eastBoundLongitude>
                            <gmd:southBoundLatitude>
                                <gco:Decimal>49.025814</gco:Decimal>
                            </gmd:southBoundLatitude>
                            <gmd:northBoundLatitude>
                                <gco:Decimal>49.153128</gco:Decimal>
                            </gmd:northBoundLatitude>
                        </gmd:EX_GeographicBoundingBox>
                    </gmd:geographicElement>
                    <gmd:temporalElement>
                        <gmd:EX_TemporalExtent>
                            <gmd:extent>
                                <gml:TimePeriod gml:id="TimePeriod">
                                    <gml:description>seconds</gml:description>

                                    <gml:endPosition>2023-10-23T00:00:00+00:00</gml:endPosition>
                                </gml:TimePeriod>

                        </gmd:EX_TemporalExtent>
                    </gmd:temporalElement>
                    <gmd:verticalElement>
                        <gmd:EX_VerticalExtent>
                        <gmd:minimumValue gco:nilReason="missing" />

    </gmd:identificationInfo>

keywords_translation_method.fr: Keyword text translated using the Amazon translate service / texte traduit à l'aide du service Amazon translate

name: 10-25976-33tj-bs38
notes:
Surface water quality monitoring is critical in determining if water quality is meeting the needs of the aquatic environment and requirements for human and livestock use. Water monitoring is also a critical component in watershed management and often is an accurate indicator of adjacent land use and management. The program measures water quality in three main parameters:
- Physical (e.g., dissolved oxygen, water temperature and total suspended solids) 
- Chemical (e.g., nutrients, metals, pesticides) 
- Biological (e.g., bacteria) 
The MRWCC has partnered with Alberta Environment and Parks, and the Counties of Warner, Cardston, and Cypress to conduct a water monitoring program on the Milk River and its tributaries since 2006.
Sampling starts in April and completed October each year. Long term monitoring is essential as data is analyzed to detect changes or trends in water sample results. In the event that the findings of the water quality fall below the established guidelines because of human activities, the MRWCC works to implement reasonable and practical measures to improve the instream water quality.
The full summary of baseline water quality sampling is reported in the 2nd Edition Milk River Transboundary State of the Watershed Report and can be accessed at: www.mrwcc.ca

notes_translated.en:
Surface water quality monitoring is critical in determining if water quality is meeting the needs of the aquatic environment and requirements for human and livestock use. Water monitoring is also a critical component in watershed management and often is an accurate indicator of adjacent land use and management. The program measures water quality in three main parameters:
- Physical (e.g., dissolved oxygen, water temperature and total suspended solids) 
- Chemical (e.g., nutrients, metals, pesticides) 
- Biological (e.g., bacteria) 
The MRWCC has partnered with Alberta Environment and Parks, and the Counties of Warner, Cardston, and Cypress to conduct a water monitoring program on the Milk River and its tributaries since 2006.
Sampling starts in April and completed October each year. Long term monitoring is essential as data is analyzed to detect changes or trends in water sample results. In the event that the findings of the water quality fall below the established guidelines because of human activities, the MRWCC works to implement reasonable and practical measures to improve the instream water quality.
The full summary of baseline water quality sampling is reported in the 2nd Edition Milk River Transboundary State of the Watershed Report and can be accessed at: www.mrwcc.ca
notes_translated.fr:
La surveillance de la qualité des eaux de surface est essentielle pour déterminer si la qualité de l'eau répond aux besoins du milieu aquatique et aux exigences relatives à l'utilisation humaine et animale. La surveillance de l'eau est également un élément essentiel de la gestion des bassins versants et constitue souvent un indicateur précis de l'utilisation et de la gestion des terres adjacentes. Le programme mesure la qualité de l'eau selon trois paramètres principaux :
- Physique (par exemple, oxygène dissous, température de l'eau et total des solides en suspension) 
- Produit chimique (nutriments, métaux, pesticides, etc.) 
- Biologique (par exemple, bactéries) 
Le MRWCC s'est associé à Alberta Environment and Parks et aux comtés de Warner, Cardston et Cypress pour mener un programme de surveillance de l'eau sur la rivière Milk et ses affluents depuis 2006.
L'échantillonnage commence en avril et se termine en octobre de chaque année. La surveillance à long terme est essentielle car les données sont analysées pour détecter les changements ou les tendances dans les résultats des échantillons d'eau. Dans le cas où les résultats de la qualité de l'eau seraient inférieurs aux recommandations établies en raison des activités humaines, le MRWCC s'efforce de mettre en œuvre des mesures raisonnables et pratiques pour améliorer la qualité de l'eau dans les cours d'eau.
Le résumé complet de l'échantillonnage de référence pour la qualité de l'eau est présenté dans la 2e édition du rapport sur l'état du bassin versant transfrontalier de Milk River et peut être consulté à l'adresse suivante : www.mrwcc.ca

notes_translation_method.fr: Description text translated using the Amazon translate service / texte traduit à l'aide du service Amazon translate

description_translated.en: DataStream is an open access platform for sharing water and sediment quality data.
description_translated.fr: DataStream est une plateforme en libre accès pour partager des données sur la qualité de l'eau et des sédiments.

title: Milk River Watershed Council Canada Water Quality Monitoring

title_translated.fr: Surveillance de la qualité de l'eau par le Conseil canadien du bassin versant de Milk River
